resource.chars:
Siphonophora. In the group of Polyps we see 
that colonial forms more or less concen-
trated preceded the solitary Malacodermata -
- it is to say - the forms more compound 
of whole class. In the strange group 
of Tunicata we find the colonial forms 
between the compound <u>Ascidias <\u> and these 
forms gave doubtless the origine to more 
developed and larger forms of compli-
cated <u>Ascidias <\u>.
The colonial forms of Bryozoa gave the 
more developed and large forms of <u>Loxo-
soma <\u> and we can suppose that some 
forms of Worms (as a <u>Foronis <\u>) arose 
from such a great group. We can 
suppose also that some forms of Pla-
naria find their origin in the same group 
of Worms in very little colonial pa-
rasites as a form discovered by professor 
<u>Owsjannikow <\u> in the eggs of Sturionida.
With these forms conclude the series 
of colonial organisms and following hi-
gher groups complicate themselves by 
simple solitary forms, but bound in tem-
poral or constant society.
If we will resume all these facts we 
can make the following general conclusions.
1o The developement of forms in lowest ani-
mal’s life principally becomes by means of 
the colonial forms, which are undergoing the 
law of concentration of organs.
